messages: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:51): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, did you fix the <p> <span> <ol> thingie?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:51): I guess nobody e-mailed about that
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:53): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: what would need to be done for sections?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:00): dunno, haven't looked in that folder :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:00): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: what issue?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:01): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, nesting <ol> inside <p> through means of a <span>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:01): it's already in the spec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:01): it's commented out
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:01): search for XXXSPAN
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:02): the spec has "<p class="big-issue">This doesn't match browsers.</p>"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:02): '<p><i><div><p>'
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:02): so maybe that's different
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:04): seems to be similar anyway
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:04): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, in the parsing section there doesn't seem to be XXXSPAN
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:05): oh i misunderstood which issue you meant
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:05): yes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:05): i have no idea how to fix that particular issue
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:05): and intend to not fix it unless someone can come up with a better solution :-)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:07): you're hoping browsers will change?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:08): yes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:12): hm
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:13): maybe it's just a matter of not closing ps unless the current element is a p
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:18): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I vote for having a sane ruby spec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:32): no, it's more complicated than that, because i'd have to make <p> not look through non-formatting non-phrasing elements
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:56): ruby is fine with me too
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:57): i hope browsers will implement it at some point

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:59): Is it allowed to ask you not to work on alt or abbr but to not mind otherwise? (because working on alt or abbr is a waste of everyone's time since there are people who will object whatever the spec says, so we will have to revisit the issue again anyway)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:00): instead of asking that, you could just vote for the other options

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:00): (unless by "work on alt" you mean "organise some proper non-automated study into the way that @alt is used on the internet and how that varies with the other properties of the page" rather than "change the spec text about alt")
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:00): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, what's the problem with abbr? who would object?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:01): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: There is a dormant prema-thread about abbr, no?

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:03): oh, you mean that one where some people want to preserve the theoretical differences between abbr and acronym and add more attributes for fine grained control over them?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:04): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: i have to reply to the feedback at some point
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:04): the only good solution is to make abbr and acronym synonymous, since people use them interchangebly anyway.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:05): or just leave it as is with only abbr
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:05): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: in fact, as far as i can tell, what the spec says is closer to what IE does than what the other browsers do
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:05): it's also what firefox does

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:06): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I know. But replying only has the effect of generating more feedback so if you prioritize those areas then you will never get anything else done
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:06): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, my Firefox allows <p><span><ol>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:07): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: yes, it has a special case for <span>, but only <span>
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:08): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, works for <i> too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:08): not for me
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:08): <!DOCTYPE html><p><i><p>x</p></i></p>x
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:08): is what I used
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:08): <!DOCTYPE html><p><i><ol><li>test</li></ol></i></p>x
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:09): works too
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:09): but it starts breaking down if you leave out some end tag
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:09): quite messy
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:10): oh, you're including end tags
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:10): well then sure
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:10): firefox has a differet mode for that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:10): if all the tags match it just does exactly what the markup is most of hte time
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:10): interesting
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:11): in any case what the spec does is still closer to what IE does
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:11): even for <span>

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:11): http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C!DOCTYPE%20html%3E%3Cstyle%3Ep%20{%20border%3A%20solid%20fuchsia%3B%20padding%3A%200.5em%3B%20}%20div%20{%20border%3A%20solid%20teal%3B%20padding%3A%200.5em%3B%20}%3C%2Fstyle%3E%0A...%3Ctable%3E%3Ctr%3E%3Ctd%3E%3Cp%3E%3Ci%3E%3Cdiv%3E%3Cp%3E%3C%2Ftable%3E%0A...%3Ctable%3E%3Ctr%3E%3Ctd%3E%3Cp%3E%3Cspan%3E%3Cdiv%3E%3Cp%3E%3C%2Ftable%3E%0A
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:13): ok
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:16): in fact for this:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:16): <!DOCTYPE html>...<p><span><p>...</p></span></p>...
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:16): the DOM that HTML5 gives is as close to what IE does as you can get without the non-tree DOM thing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:16): and much cloer than what other browsers do
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:17): in fact that particular case matches webkit pretty well
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:18): and opera's rendering doesn't match its DOM
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:18): goes to remove the issue marker
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:20): wow, video codec contains a lot of e-mails
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:21): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, "Error loading folder contents: . Let 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e know."
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:22): (stuff still works, so I'm not sure what's going on)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:23): weird
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:23): let me know if it can be reproduced
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:24): after a refresh it's no longer there
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:24): probably just memory issues on my server
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:24): btw, there's WF3-geo and geolocation
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:24): yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:24): i'm not looking there until webapi decides what they're doing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:24): or until the forms tf completes
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:25): not really sure what to do there
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:25): Forms WG still seems fixed on the idea of bringing XForms to HTML
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:26): well since that's not in the forms tf charter, that should be easy to deal with
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:28): the latest was http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-forms-tf/2008May/0003.html
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:28): goes to look at his ruby data
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:28): yeah i saw
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:33): I note that nobody replied to http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-forms-tf/2008Apr/0023.html
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:35): maybe it would be best to draft a new text document taking guidelines 1-7 from maciej and propose to adopt that
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:35): I might have time this weekend
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:36): it probably doesn't have to be HTML per se, you could just do it like the charter document
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:38): you mean you actually want to do the work the tf chartered itself to do?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:38): that's a radical idea
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:38): it'll never catch on
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:40): hmm, seems that my browser couldn't handle the sarcasm
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:42): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, for your issues graph, it would be nicer if the horizontal line snapped to the nearest graph
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:45): yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:46): so according to my data
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:46): there are a lot of stray </rt> elements
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:46): but not many stray </rp> elements
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:47): despite there being roughly the same amount of both
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:48): that's a very odd result
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:49): hmm, </ruby> has about the same problem
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:49): as </rt>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:49): i clearly need to do this again but get sample urls
